briefdescription.para: Addresses from these networks are not publicly routable on the global Internet.

detaileddescription.para: A set of addresses that represent the hash of a string or FQDN. We use them in AddrMan to keep track of which DNS seeds were used.

briefdescription.para: Dummy value to indicate the number of NET_* constants.

detaileddescription.para:
A network type.
An address may belong to more than one network, for example 10.0.0.1 belongs to both NET_UNROUTABLE and NET_IPV4. Keep these sequential starting from 0 and NET_MAX as the last entry. We have loops like for (int i = 0; i < NET_MAX; ++i) that expect to iterate over all enum values and also GetExtNetwork() "extends" this enum by introducing standalone constants starting from NET_MAX.
Prefix of an IPv6 address when it contains an embedded IPv4 address. Used when (un)serializing addresses in ADDRv1 format (pre-BIP155).

Prefix of an IPv6 address when it contains an embedded TORv2 address. Used when (un)serializing addresses in ADDRv1 format (pre-BIP155). Such dummy IPv6 addresses are guaranteed to not be publicly routable as they fall under RFC4193's fc00::/7 subnet allocated to unique-local addresses.

Prefix of an IPv6 address when it contains an embedded "internal" address. Used when (un)serializing addresses in ADDRv1 format (pre-BIP155). The prefix comes from 0xFD + SHA256("bitcoin")[0:5]. Such dummy IPv6 addresses are guaranteed to not be publicly routable as they fall under RFC4193's fc00::/7 subnet allocated to unique-local addresses.
All CJDNS addresses start with 0xFC. See https://github.com/cjdelisle/cjdns/blob/master/doc/Whitepaper.md#pulling-it-all-together
Size of TORv3 address (in bytes). This is the length of just the address as used in BIP155, without the checksum and the version byte.

briefdescription.para: SAM 3.1 and earlier do not support specifying ports and force the port to 0.
